title: Understanding the Information Cycle
text: The information cycle refers to the progression of a news event's coverage over time. Different types of media tend to report on events at different times in this cycle.

title: Immediate vs. Later Coverage
text: Immediately after an event, you'll likely find information on real-time platforms such as social media or the Internet. Newspapers typically follow with more detailed reports.

title: What Newspapers Offer
text: Newspapers primarily provide detailed news coverage of recent events, usually within a day or two after the event has occurred. They gather information, verify facts, and present a comprehensive story.

title: Understanding the Characteristics of Each Option
text:
- **Internet:** Offers real-time and unverified information right after an event.
- **Newspaper:** Offers verified and detailed information typically the day after the event.
- **Academic Journal:** Provides in-depth analysis and research-based articles, often weeks to months later.
- **Reference Book:** Offers historical accounts and is not suitable for current events.
